Posts.Title: Bimmer, I told Oprah GeetasMom GEECH

Posts.Content: Dec 7, 2007 10:02AM - edited Dec 7, 2007 12:04PM by MtnMama Sue -- You're right that the test helps determine the treatment, but the most effective part of the treatment to obliterate the cancer from your body can be direct removal of any known or likely cancer cells.  Chemo, radiation, and hormonal treatments in the majority of cases are effective.  But there are no guarantees, so it's all about balancing the risks. You raise some really good questions about lymphedema risks.  I would discuss them with your onc, and even get a second opinion if needed.  I would have probably made the same choices as LindaLou53 if faced with her decisions.

Posts.Content: Dec 13, 2007 01:49AM MtnMama wrote: This is such a hard time, the waiting for results.  Even if it is cancer there are so many options for you.  Once the diagnosis is done, that's when you would get to plan the treatment to knock it out so you can get your life back.  Please do come back and let us know what the doctor says tomorrow.
Posts.Title: Bad Biopsy Jenn51 HeatherBLocklear

Posts.Content: Jan 4, 2008 06:07PM - edited Jan 4, 2008 06:08PM by MtnMama Be diligent about checking on CBC results.  I was feeling good, so didn't follow up.  I figured no news was good news.  Since I wasn't getting the blood draws at the cancer center, but instead a local hospital, the ball got dropped.  I was severely neutropenic for a week before being notified. Two months ago, several months post chemo, I got severe food poisoning from a local pizza place.  If that had happened when I was neutropenic, it could have been fatal.  So that's the second bit of advice!  Don't eat out unless you've recently checked your WBC!
Posts.Title: Chemo no, no's? Diana63 Diana63

Posts.Content: Jan 4, 2008 06:10PM MtnMama wrote: The other thing I found helpful to do (a "yes yes") is to keep as physically active as you can manage.  Exercise, clean the house, do physical projects (I was doing a renovation, so sanded boards and painted walls).  Since the chemo one-two doesn't set in immediately, by starting activity immediately post treatment I staved off the onset and the severity of the side effects.  I gave this advice to a co-worker now going through chemo, and she says that it has helped her, too.
Posts.Title: Chemo no, no's? Diana63 Diana63

Posts.Content: Dec 4, 2007 10:55AM MtnMama wrote: Barb, my weight was absolutely stable during chemo and I didn't have any problems eating.  Some of my favorite foods didn't taste particularly good, but I found others. I also had neo-adjuvent chemo to shrink the tumor before surgery.  I'm so glad I did if for no other reason than to read the words on the follow-up MRI report:  "There is no evidence of any mass or suspicous enhancement in either breast.  There is no abnormality identified at the site of the previously diagnosed breast cancer... Clearly there has been a response to the chemotherapy."  !!! My tumor was 2.5 cm at the time of my first MRI (larger than dx partially due to hematoma, but also a fast growing grade 3). I hope you get a similar report in the coming months!

Posts.Content: Apr 20, 2008 08:46PM MtnMama wrote: It's hard to tell for me when mine shrank because my lump had swelled to 2.7 cm from 1.0 from the biopsy (helluva hematoma).   It wasn't until 2 weeks after my 4th and final AC course that I had an MRI to measure shrinkage ... and there was no detection of it, at all. The different drugs work on different patients.  I was lucky that AC did it for me, as I opted to not do Taxotere.
Posts.Title: neoadjuvant chemo - but tumor not shrinking? Emma56 carpediempenny

Posts.Content: Dec 4, 2007 05:50PM MtnMama wrote: Karen, I'm so sorry about your recent diagnosis.  I so relate to your POV, as I was there 8 months ago.  At the time, all I knew was that I had a 1 cm IDC tumor since I didn't have the node results back yet.  I wanted both breasts gone, ASAP. I opted to do chemo before surgery though, and that gave me time to learn more.  Because my tumor was grade 3, I wanted to start chemo as soon as possible to try to knock out anything elsewhere, and I also wanted to see how effective the chemo would be (seeing the tumor shrink).  I am so glad I did have that time, because my perspective on surgery changed.  I ended up having a lumpectomy with radiation instead, and don't regret my decision one bit.  I am now facing a scare with a suspicious bone scan, but choosing a mastectomy would not have changed that. One thing I discussed with my surgeon that made my decision for lumpectomy clearer, is that once you've been dx'ed, you are under very close supervision.  I will be seeing  a cancer doc every 3 months getting blood tests and clinical breast exams, and I'll be getting an MRI or mammogram every six months. The first couple months of diagnosis was worse than any treatment I endured, so there will be sunshine for you.  Hang in there.
Posts.Title: BRCA test impact on surgery twogirls SandyinSoCal

Posts.Content: Dec 4, 2007 03:33PM - edited Dec 4, 2007 04:34PM by MtnMama dink, DCIS is carcinoma (that's the "C"), so there are cells that are dividing and, left unchecked, could become invasive and enter your lymphatic system and bloodstream.  So DCIS has one of the three attributes of cancer, and as your doc says is "pre-"cancer.  On the other hand, your dx appears to be bc stage 0 (although your profile says stage I)... so you have breast cancer.  Confusing, eh? On your other question, testing that I have had for ovarian cancer (ultrasound) was not dependent on my uterus.

Posts.Content: Dec 12, 2007 10:13PM MtnMama wrote: Fear is a funny thing ... The only times I broke down and cried since this whole ride started was between the ultrasound and the radiologist report, and when the oncologist told me that my lymph nodes were clear.  I never broke down when I got the radiologist report, the initial IDC dx from path, the high grade, the thin margin.  It was first the uncertainty and then the good news. Stress release can manifest itself in anxiety.  With time I'm certain your defenses will drop and let you get back to living without fear.  But I'm sure you will carry this experience with you, for the better!  It will keep you diligent in getting things checked out. I sincerely hope you never have to join this club!
